message.content:
Step 1: Calculate the Current Ratio  
• From the balance sheet, Total Current Assets = 9,625,738.03 and Total Current Liabilities = 628,478.02.  
• Current Ratio = 9,625,738.03 / 628,478.02 ≈ 15.32

Step 2: Calculate the Quick Ratio  
• Quick Assets exclude Inventory. Here, “quick assets” are computed by summing:  
 – Cash on Hand = 3,057,369.78  
 – Bank Deposits = 4,292,000.00  
 – Interest Receivable = 14,575.80  
 – Accounts Receivable = 2,149,792.45  
• Total Quick Assets = 3,057,369.78 + 4,292,000.00 + 14,575.80 + 2,149,792.45 = 9,513,738.03  
• Quick Ratio = 9,513,738.03 / 628,478.02 ≈ 15.14

Step 3: Calculate the Debt to Asset Ratio  
• Total Liabilities = Total Current Liabilities = 628,478.02 (no long‐term liabilities provided)  
• Total Assets = 14,534,228.78  
• Debt to Asset Ratio = 628,478.02 / 14,534,228.78 ≈ 0.04

Step 4: Calculate the Debt to Equity Ratio  
• Total Owner’s Equity from the balance sheet = 13,905,750.76  
• Debt to Equity Ratio = 628,478.02 / 13,905,750.76 ≈ 0.05

Step 5: Calculate the Cash Flow to Debt Ratio  
• From the cash flow statement, Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –650,630.22  
• Debt (we use total liabilities) = 628,478.02  
• Cash Flow to Debt Ratio = –650,630.22 / 628,478.02 ≈ –1.04

Thus, the final solution is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Current Ratio": "15.32",
    "Quick Ratio": "15.14",
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.04",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.05",
    "Cash Flow to Debt Ratio": "-1.04"
  }
}
